subject: Cybersecurity
title: TCP/IP: The Language of the Internet
description: A short lesson to help you apply TCP/IP: The Language of the Internet.

hook.text: The internet was designed for resilience in nuclear war, not for security. That design choice haunts us today.

buildup.text: TCP/IP was created for ARPANET. It breaks data into packets, routes them independently, and reassembles them at.

discovery.text: TCP ensures reliable delivery with handshakes and acknowledgments. IP handles addressing and routing across networks.

twist.text: TCP/IP has no built-in authentication or encryption. Any device can claim to be any IP address. Trust was assumed.

climax.text: Every security protocol we layer on top (TLS, IPsec, DNSSEC) is patching the trust that TCP/IP assumed but.

punchline.text: The internet works on trust. It was never designed to be suspicious.

quiz.question: Why is TCP/IP considered insecure by design?
options: It's too slow for modern networks
It was designed for resilience, not security, with no built-in authentication
It can only handle small data transfers
